newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch money dealers clear books ahead of expiry.
newsitem.headline: Dutch money dealers clear books ahead of expiry.

text.p: Dutch money dealers, clearing their books ahead of the first cash reserve expiry on Friday under the Dutch central bank's new money market policy, said the market had enough liquidity.
"Call money rates remain stable at 2.75 percent bid and there seems to be enough liquidity around," said one dealer.
Market players are not allowed to show a debit balance on their cash reserve account at the central bank at the end of the trading day under the new system.
"Liquidity in the market looks to be in balance although there might be an incidental liquidity gap," said one.
The dealer said there was enough liquidity in the market to fill such a small gap, adding there was a greater chance that a few players had ample liquidity.
"Several participants have been saving under the scheme as they were not completely familiar with the central banks' new money market policy at the start," said another dealer.
Participants with a debit balance on their cash reserve account at the end of a trading day have to obtain overnight credit at the marginal advance facility rate of 4.5 percent.
Market players will not receive any return on their surplus.
There was little interest for the two new Dutch Treasury Certificate programmes (DTCs), short term borrowing programmes of the Dutch government, which went on sale today.
The new three-month DTCs, running until September 30, 1997, were priced at 3.09 percent and the 12-month programme, running until June 30, 1998, was priced at 3.21 percent.
"This is not a good price," said one dealer, adding the Dutch government probably had enough liquidity in stock.
"They might raise the price for the outstanding DTC programmes on Monday as they probably need liquidity to pay off the DTC programme that runs until June 30, 1997," he said.
The June 1997 programme had raised 7.5 billion guilders.
The guilder was slightly stronger versus the mark at 112.5275 per 100 marks compared to 112.555 on Wednesday.
Dealers said the special advances rate will most likely remain at 2.90 percent when the central bank sets a new pact this afternoon at 1400 GMT.
"The allocation on the new pact tomorrow will probably be less ample than the previous one," said one dealer.
Individual banks received 28.8 percent of the amount they had applied for under this seven-day pact, with the central bank setting a ceiling of 4.07 billion guilders on applications.
"The new pact will probably meet individual banks' applications up to 14 or 15 percent under the new pact," the dealer said.
He said the current allocation had been sufficient because banks with a small liquidity gap could solve this with the central banks' allocation.
-- Wendy Braanker, Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000
